question: Why does industry primarily use drawings to describe objects?

options.b: To avoid possible errors in communication
options.c: To reduce material costs

explanation: Industry uses drawings to describe objects primarily to avoid possible errors that can arise from oral or written communication alone (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 9).

question: In engineering applications, what do lines in graphic language primarily represent?

options.b: Surfaces, edges, and contours of objects
options.c: Manufacturing processes

explanation: Graphic language in engineering uses lines to represent the surfaces, edges, and contours of objects (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 16).

question: What is the main purpose of a detail drawing?

options.a: To show the relationship between multiple parts
options.b: To describe a single part with all its specifications
options.c: To illustrate the final installed position of an assembly

explanation: A detail drawing provides a complete description of a single part, including its size, shape, material, and manufacturing methods (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 35).

question: What information does an installation drawing primarily provide?

options.a: The internal structure of a single component
options.b: The manufacturing process for an assembly
options.c: The final installed position of a part or assembly in the aircraft

explanation: An installation drawing includes all necessary information for a part or an assembly in its final installed position within the aircraft (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 40).

question: Which of the following is a primary use of a T-square in drafting?

options.b: Measuring angles
options.c: Drawing horizontal lines

explanation: A T-square is primarily used for drawing horizontal lines and guiding triangles (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 51).

question: In the grading of drawing pencils, which lead is generally considered the hardest?

options.b: HB
options.c: 9H

explanation: Drawing pencil leads range in hardness, with 9H being the hardest and 6B being the softest (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 67).

question: What is the main purpose of using drawing standards?

options.b: To ensure drawings convey the same meaning to everyone
options.c: To reduce the time taken to create drawings

explanation: Drawing standards are used so that drawings convey the same meaning to everyone who reads them, ensuring uniform representation (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 73).

question: What is the purpose of a hidden line in a drawing?

options.a: To show the center of a circular feature
options.b: To indicate invisible edges or contours
options.c: To mark the dimensions of an object

explanation: Hidden lines, typically medium weight, are used to indicate edges or contours that are not visible from the current view (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 83).

question: What is 'tolerance' in the context of engineering drawings and dimensioning?

options.a: The ideal size of a part
options.b: The difference between the high and low limits of a dimension
options.c: The material specification for a part

explanation: Tolerance is the permissible variation in a dimension, defined as the difference between the high (maximum) and low (minimum) limits of size (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 102).

question: What is the primary purpose of a sectional view in a technical drawing?

options.a: To show the exterior appearance of an object
options.b: To reveal the internal shape and construction of an object
options.c: To provide a list of materials for an object

explanation: A sectional view is used to show the internal shape and construction of an object by depicting it as if a portion has been cut away (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 249).

question: What is 'graphic language' in the context of engineering?

options.a: A type of computer programming language
options.b: A visual means of communication using lines and symbols
options.c: A spoken language used by engineers

explanation: Graphic language is a visual language developed to be a technical and accurate means of communication, using lines and symbols (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 10, 19).

question: Which of these is NOT a primary way of creating engineering drawings?

options.b: Oral descriptions
options.c: Computer graphics (CAD)

explanation: The three basic ways of creating technical drawings are freehand sketches, instrument drawings, and computer graphics. Oral descriptions are a means of communication but not a primary drawing creation method (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 21).

question: What is the primary function of an assembly drawing?

options.a: To detail the dimensions of a single part
options.b: To show the relationship of various parts in an object
options.c: To specify the material for each component

explanation: The primary purpose of an assembly drawing is to show the relationship of the various parts that make up an object (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 37).

question: What is microfiche?

options.b: A card with pages laid out in a grid format for storing microreproductions
options.c: A digital storage device like a CD

explanation: Microfiche is a card with pages laid out in a grid format, containing microreproductions of documents (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 44, 46).

question: What are drawing templates used for?

options.b: To serve as patterns or guides for drawing standard shapes like circles and squares
options.c: To erase ink lines

explanation: Drawing templates are patterns that serve as a guide to follow, containing pre-cut shapes like circles, squares, rectangles, etc. (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 60).

question: What is the purpose of an erasing shield?

options.a: To protect the drawing paper from smudges
options.b: To allow precise erasure of small areas without disturbing nearby lines
options.c: To hold the drawing paper firmly on the board

explanation: An erasing shield is used to protect lines near the area being erased, allowing for precise removal of unwanted marks (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 63).

question: Which of the following is an example of a drawing material (consumable)?

options.b: Compass
options.c: Drawing paper

explanation: Drawing materials are items that get consumed with use, such as paper, pencil, and erasers (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 65).

question: What does the 'ANSI' standard code stand for in the context of drawing standards?

options.b: American National Standard Institute
options.c: Asian Normative Standard Initiative

explanation: ANSI stands for the American National Standard Institute, which sets drawing standards in the USA (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 74).

question: What is the standard size of an A4 drawing sheet in millimeters?
explanation: The standard trimmed size for an A4 drawing sheet is 210 x 297 millimeters (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 76).

question: What information is typically included in a drawing's title block?

options.b: Drawing number, title, company name, scale, date, drafter
options.c: A list of all parts shown in the drawing

explanation: A title block typically includes information such as the drawing number, sheet number, title, company name, logo, scale, date, tolerances, drafter, checker, and supervisor (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 79).

question: Which type of line is used to indicate the visible edge of an object?

options.b: Center line
options.c: Object line

explanation: Object lines (or visible lines) are thick lines used to indicate the visible edges of an object (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 83).

question: What is the purpose of a center line?

options.a: To show where a part is to be cut for a sectional view
options.b: To indicate the center of an object or part of an object, especially for symmetrical features
options.c: To connect a note to a specific feature on the drawing

explanation: Center lines (thin lines) are used to indicate the center of an object or part of an object, such as the axis of a hole or a symmetrical part (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 83).

question: What do section line symbols typically show on a drawing?

options.a: The direction of view for a detail
options.b: The kind of material from which the part is to be constructed
options.c: The allowable tolerance for a dimension

explanation: Section line symbols (crosshatching) show the kind of material from which the part is to be constructed when a sectional view is presented (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 86).

question: In lettering, what does 'proportion' refer to?

options.b: The height-to-width ratio of letters
options.c: The spacing between words

explanation: Proportion in lettering refers to the height-to-width ratio of the letters (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 90, 94).

question: What are 'size dimensions' used for in a drawing?

options.a: To indicate the location of features like holes
options.b: To specify the size of features, such as the diameter of holes or length of edges
options.c: To show the assembly order of parts

explanation: Size dimensions are used to define the size of features, such as the size of holes, length, width, and thickness of parts (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 100).

question: What is the term for the maximum permitted size of a dimensioned feature?

options.b: Lower limit
options.c: High limit (Upper limit)

explanation: The upper dimension shown for a feature is the maximum permitted size, also known as the high limit (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 102).

question: In geometric construction, what does it mean to 'bisect' a line?

options.b: To divide the line into two equal parts
options.c: To extend the line

explanation: Bisecting a line means to divide it into two equal parts (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 115).

question: How many sides does a pentagon have?
explanation: A pentagon is a polygon with five sides (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 120).

question: What is an ellipse?

options.a: A polygon with an infinite number of sides
options.b: A single-curved surface primitive, often appearing as a circle viewed at an angle
options.c: A three-dimensional cube

explanation: An ellipse is a single-curved surface primitive, which can be created when a plane passes through a cone at an angle, or how a circle appears when viewed obliquely (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 137).

question: What is the primary characteristic of an orthographic projection?

options.a: Lines converge to a single vanishing point
options.b: It represents a three-dimensional object using several two-dimensional views with projectors perpendicular to the projection plane
options.c: It shows the object in a distorted, artistic way

explanation: Orthographic projection is a method of representing a three-dimensional object on paper using several two-dimensional views, where projection lines are perpendicular to the projection plane (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 146, 155).

question: In perspective projection, where is the observer located relative to the object?

options.b: At a finite (fixed) distance
options.c: Directly on the picture plane

explanation: In perspective (or central) projection, the observer is located at a finite (fixed distance) from the object, causing projectors to converge (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 149).

question: What is the standard angle of projection used in the United States for orthographic views?

options.b: Second-angle projection
options.c: Third-angle projection

explanation: Third-angle projection is the standard used in the United States for arranging orthographic views (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 159).

question: How many principal views are typically used to fully describe a complex object in orthographic projection?

options.b: Three
options.c: Six, but three are usually sufficient

explanation: While there are six standard principal views, complex objects are typically described using three views (front, top, side). (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 164, 174).

question: What are the three principal dimensions of an object?

options.b: Width, Height, Depth
options.c: Radius, Diameter, Circumference

explanation: The three principal dimensions of an object are width, height, and depth (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 172).

question: What is a 'normal surface' in orthographic projection?

options.a: A surface that appears foreshortened in all principal views
options.b: A surface parallel to one of the principal projection planes, appearing true size in that view and as an edge in two others
options.c: A curved surface

explanation: A normal surface is parallel to one of the principal planes of projection and appears as an edge in two opposite principal views, and as a surface (true size) in the view parallel to it (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 179).

question: What is the rule of precedence for lines when a visible line coincides with a hidden line?

options.b: The visible line takes precedence
options.c: A centerline takes precedence over both

explanation: When lines coincide, visible lines take precedence over hidden lines and centerlines (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 183).

question: Which type of axonometric drawing has all three axes making equal angles with the plane of projection and all edges foreshortened equally?

options.b: Trimetric
options.c: Isometric

explanation: In isometric projection, all three axonometric axes make equal angles with the projection plane, and lines parallel to these axes are equally foreshortened (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 187, 189).

question: In an isometric drawing, how do circles on the object's faces appear?

options.b: As ellipses
options.c: As straight lines

explanation: In an isometric drawing, a circle on any of the isometric planes appears as an ellipse (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 201).

question: What is a key characteristic of oblique drawing?

options.b: One face of the object is parallel to the picture plane and shown in true size and shape, while receding lines are drawn at an angle
options.c: It uses multiple vanishing points

explanation: In oblique drawing, one principal face of the object is drawn parallel to the projection plane (true size and shape), and the receding lines representing depth are drawn at an angle (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 213, 156).

question: In 'cabinet' oblique drawing, how is the scale along the receding axis typically treated?

options.b: Reduced by one-half
options.c: Enlarged by double

explanation: In cabinet oblique drawing, the scale along the receding axis is reduced by one-half of that used on the front face to compensate for distortion (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 213, 214).

question: What is the main visual characteristic of perspective drawings that makes them appear realistic?

options.a: All lines are drawn to true length
options.b: Parallel lines appear to converge as they recede into the distance (foreshortening)
options.c: Objects are always shown with their front face parallel to the viewer

explanation: Perspective drawings are realistic because parallel lines are shown converging as they recede into the picture, an effect known as foreshortening (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 228).

question: In one-point perspective, how many principal faces of the object are typically parallel to the picture plane?

options.b: One
options.c: Two

explanation: In one-point perspective, the object is placed such that one of its principal faces is parallel to the picture plane, appearing true size and shape (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 237).

question: How many vanishing points are typically used in a two-point perspective drawing?

options.b: Two
options.c: Three

explanation: Two-point perspective drawing uses two vanishing points on the horizon line, where receding parallel edges converge (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 239).

question: What is a 'cutting plane line' used to indicate in a drawing?

options.b: Where an imaginary cut is made to create a sectional view
options.c: The axis of symmetry

explanation: A cutting plane line is used to designate where an imaginary cutting took place to create a sectional view (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 84, 252).

question: What is the purpose of section (crosshatching) lines in a sectional view?

options.b: To indicate the surfaces that were cut by the cutting plane
options.c: To represent the material of the object

explanation: Section lines (crosshatching) are used to indicate the surfaces of an object that have been theoretically cut by the cutting plane (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 249). They can also indicate material type (p.86).

question: In a 'full section' view, how much of the object is theoretically cut away?

options.b: One half, passing fully through the object
options.c: Only a small portion

explanation: In a full section, the cutting plane passes completely through the part, theoretically removing the front half to show the interior (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 269, 271).

question: What is a 'half section' view typically used for?

options.b: Symmetrical objects, to show both the interior and exterior in one view
options.c: Very small objects

explanation: Half sections are used with symmetrical objects to show both the interior (sectioned half) and exterior (unsectioned half) in a single view (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 273).

question: What is an 'offset section' used for?

options.a: To show a section at an angle to the main views
options.b: When important internal features do not lie in a single straight plane, allowing the cutting plane to bend
options.c: To show an enlarged detail of a small feature

explanation: An offset section is used when important features do not fall in a straight line, allowing the cutting-plane line to be bent or offset to pass through them (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 276).

question: What is a 'revolved section'?

options.a: A section that is rotated 90 degrees and shown in a different view
options.b: A cross-section of an elongated feature (like a spoke or rib) that is rotated 90 degrees and superimposed on the main view
options.c: A section that is removed from the main view and shown elsewhere, often enlarged

explanation: A revolved section shows the cross-sectional shape of a feature by imagining it rotated 90 degrees and drawn directly on the view of the feature (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 281, 287).

question: What is a 'removed section'?

options.a: A section where parts are omitted for clarity
options.b: A section view that is taken from its normal place in projection and shown elsewhere on the drawing, often to a larger scale
options.c: A section that has been erased from the drawing

explanation: A removed section is similar to a revolved section but is placed at one side (removed from the main view) and often drawn to a larger scale to show detail (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 288).

question: What is a 'broken-out section' used for?

options.a: To show the entire interior of an object
options.b: To section a small portion of a drawing to reveal interior detail without a formal cutting plane line
options.c: To indicate a part that is broken and needs repair

explanation: A broken-out section is used to section a small portion of a drawing to show interior detail, using an irregular break line instead of a cutting plane line (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 294).

question: Which of these parts are generally NOT sectioned even if the cutting plane passes through them lengthwise?

options.b: Engine blocks
options.c: Shafts, bolts, pins, rivets

explanation: Shafts, bolts, pins, rivets, and similar solid items are generally not sectioned when the cutting plane passes through them lengthwise because they have no internal details to show (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 301).

question: What is an auxiliary view primarily used to show?

options.a: A magnified view of a small part
options.b: The true shape and size of an inclined surface that is not parallel to any of the principal projection planes
options.c: An exploded view of an assembly

explanation: An auxiliary view is an orthographic view projected onto a plane that is not parallel to any of the principal planes, used to show the true shape and size of an inclined surface (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 305).

question: What is a 'primary auxiliary view' projected onto?

options.a: A plane parallel to all principal planes
options.b: A plane perpendicular to one principal plane and inclined to the other two
options.c: A plane inclined to all three principal projection planes

explanation: A primary auxiliary view is projected on a plane that is perpendicular to one of the principal planes of projection and is inclined to the other two (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 309).

question: What is the main purpose of a schematic diagram?

options.a: To show the exact size and location of components in an aircraft
options.b: To illustrate the principle of operation of a system by showing components and their relationships symbolically
options.c: To provide detailed manufacturing instructions for a part

explanation: Schematic diagrams show the principle of operation of a system, locating components with respect to each other symbolically, and are often used for troubleshooting and training (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 321).

question: What type of diagram uses rectangles (blocks) to show a simplified relationship of a complex system of components?

options.b: Installation diagram
options.c: Block diagram

explanation: Block diagrams are used to show a simplified relationship of a more complex system of components, where individual components are drawn as rectangles (blocks) (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 324).

question: What information does a wiring diagram typically show?

options.b: The electrical wiring and circuitry, coded for identification
options.c: The hydraulic fluid flow in a system

explanation: Wiring diagrams show the electrical wiring and circuitry, coded for identification, of all electrical appliances and devices (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 326).

question: What are troubleshooting flowcharts frequently used for?

options.b: For the detection of faulty components, often using a series of yes/no questions
options.c: To illustrate the assembly sequence of parts

explanation: Troubleshooting flowcharts are frequently used for the detection of faulty components and often consist of a series of yes or no questions to guide the diagnostic process (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 329, 330, 331).

question: What is the ATA Specification No. 100 used for?

options.a: To specify the materials used in aircraft construction
options.b: To establish a standard for the presentation of technical data by aircraft manufacturers
options.c: To define the flight characteristics of an aircraft

explanation: The ATA Specification No. 100 is used by the Air Transport Association of America to establish a standard for the presentation of technical data by aircraft, engine, or component manufacturers (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 339).

question: In the ATA 100 numbering system, what does the first element (Chapter) typically represent?

options.b: The aircraft system or major zone
options.c: The page number within the manual

explanation: In the ATA 100 numbering system, the first two-digit element represents the Chapter, which usually corresponds to an aircraft system (e.g., Air Conditioning, Autoflight) or a major zone (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 348, and chapter examples on p. 340-346).

question: Which drafting tool is used to draw circles and arcs?

options.b: French Curve
options.c: Compass

explanation: A compass is a drawing tool used to draw circles and arcs (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 57).

question: What is the purpose of a 'leader line' in a drawing?

options.a: To indicate the overall length of an object
options.b: To connect a note, number, or other reference to a specific part or portion of the drawing
options.c: To show the direction of a cutting plane

explanation: A leader line (thin line with an arrowhead or dot) is used to indicate a part or portion to which a note, number, or other reference applies (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 84).

question: What is the primary advantage of using CAD for creating drawings?

options.a: It is always cheaper than manual drafting
options.b: Ease of modification, storage, and communication (networking)
options.c: It requires less skill than manual drafting

explanation: Computer Aided Drafting (CAD) offers advantages like ease of modification, ability to view in virtual reality, check for interferences, and ease of communication via networking (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 24, 26).

question: What is 'lettering' in technical drawing?

options.a: The artistic style of the drawing
options.b: The process of forming letters, numerals, and other characters on a drawing
options.c: The border around the drawing sheet

explanation: Lettering is the process of forming letters, numerals, and other characters in technical drawing (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 89).

question: What does 'dimensioning' in a drawing primarily define?

options.a: The color scheme of the object
options.b: The size, form, and location of geometric features
options.c: The weight of the object

explanation: Dimensioning is the process of defining the size, form, and location of geometric features and components on an engineering drawing (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 98).

question: If a drawing scale is '1:2', what does this mean?

options.a: The drawing is twice the size of the actual object
options.b: The drawing is half the size of the actual object
options.c: The drawing is the same size as the actual object

explanation: A scale of 1:2 means the drawing is reduced, representing the object at half its actual size (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 56).

question: What is a 'phantom line' used to indicate?

options.a: The outline of a hidden part
options.b: The alternate position of parts or the relative position of a missing part
options.c: A line that will be erased later

explanation: Phantom lines are used to indicate the alternate position of parts of the object or the relative position of a missing part (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 84).

question: What type of drawing is best for showing the internal workings of a complex assembly by theoretically cutting it open?

options.b: Sectional view
options.c: Auxiliary view

explanation: Sectional views are used to describe the interior portions of an object that are otherwise difficult to visualize, by showing it as if cut open (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 249, 251).

question: What is the 'station point' in perspective projection?

options.a: The center of the object being drawn
options.b: The point where the observer's eye is located
options.c: A point on the horizon line

explanation: The station point (or point of sight) is the point where the eye of the observer is located for the resulting perspective projection (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 149, 231).

question: Which of the following is a key consideration for the care and use of drawings?

options.a: Making notes directly on the print for quick reference
options.b: Folding the drawing sharply to fit in small spaces
options.c: Keeping hands clean and avoiding placing objects on the drawing

explanation: Hands should be free of oil or grease, and drawings should not have objects placed on them or be marked, to preserve their clarity and integrity (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 31, 32).

question: What is a 'break line' used for in a drawing?

options.a: To show where a part is broken and needs repair
options.b: To indicate that a portion of the object is not shown on the drawing, usually to save space
options.c: To separate different views of an object

explanation: Break lines indicate that a portion of the object is not shown on the drawing, often used for long parts where the full length isn't needed for detail (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 84).

question: What is the purpose of a 'viewing plane line' (or cutting plane line for sections)?

options.a: To indicate the material of the object
options.b: To indicate the direction of sight when a partial view or section is used
options.c: To show the overall dimensions of the object

explanation: A viewing line (often similar to a cutting plane line) is used to indicate the direction of sight when a partial view is used. Cutting plane lines specifically show direction of sight for sections (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 84, 253).

question: What does 'orthographic' mean in the context of projection?

options.b: Draw at right angle
options.c: Drawn to scale

explanation: The term 'Orthographic' is derived from words 'Ortho' (right or straight) and 'graphics' (drawing), meaning to draw at a right angle, referring to projectors being perpendicular to the plane (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 155).

question: In isometric drawing, what is an 'isometric line'?

options.b: A line that runs parallel to any of the isometric axes
options.c: A curved line

explanation: An isometric line is a line that runs parallel to any of the three isometric axes. True-length distances are shown along these lines (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 192).

question: What is the 'horizon line' (HL) in perspective drawing?

options.a: The bottom edge of the picture plane
options.b: An imaginary horizontal plane at the observer's eye level, where vanishing points lie
options.c: The line representing the ground

explanation: The horizon line is the line of intersection of the horizon plane (at observer's eye level) with the picture plane, along which vanishing points lie (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 232).

question: If a cutting plane line has arrows pointing to the left for a front view section, where would the sectioned view typically be placed?

options.b: To the right of the front view (as a right-side section)
options.c: To the left of the front view (as a left-side section)

explanation: The arrows on a cutting plane line indicate the direction of sight. If they point left for a section shown in place of a front view, it implies the section is viewed from the right, replacing the left side view, or if section is in front view, it means the cut is from right side. The question is slightly ambiguous, but typically direction of sight determines the view. (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 253, general projection principles).

question: Which type of line is thin and used to show the termination of a dimension line?

options.b: Extension line
options.c: Center line

explanation: Extension lines are thin lines used to show the termination of a dimension line, extending from the feature being dimensioned (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 83, 99).

question: What is the primary difference between a 'revolved section' and a 'removed section'?

options.b: Revolved sections are superimposed on the view, while removed sections are placed elsewhere
options.c: Removed sections do not use section lines

explanation: A revolved section is drawn directly on the view, while a removed section is placed at one side and often drawn to a larger scale (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 287, 288, 290).

question: What is the purpose of 'geometric constructions' in drafting?

options.b: To accurately create basic geometric elements like points, lines, arcs, and polygons
options.c: To calculate material strength

explanation: Geometric constructions are methods to accurately draw basic geometric elements and shapes which form the basis of more complex drawings (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 114).

question: In axonometric projection, if two angles between the axes and the projection plane are equal, and the third is different, what type is it?

options.b: Dimetric
options.c: Trimetric

explanation: In dimetric projection, two of the three angles between the axonometric axes and the plane of projection are equal, and two axes are equally foreshortened (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 187).

question: What is the 'alphabet of lines'?

options.b: A standardized system of different line types and weights used in drawings to convey specific meanings
options.c: The order in which lines should be drawn

explanation: The alphabet of lines is a set of standard line types (e.g., visible, hidden, center) with specific conventions for their appearance and use to ensure clear communication in drawings (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 81, 83-84).

question: What is the typical angle for section lines (crosshatching)?

options.b: 45 degrees to the main outline or axis of the part
options.c: Parallel to the object outline

explanation: Section lines are generally drawn at an angle of 45 degrees to the principal outlines or axes of the sectioned part (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 265, though not explicitly stated, this is standard practice shown in examples).

question: What is the 'ground line' (GL) in perspective drawing?

options.a: The line representing the observer's eye level
options.b: The line of intersection of the ground plane with the picture plane
options.c: The outline of the object on the ground

explanation: The ground line is the line of intersection of the ground plane (on which the object rests) with the picture plane (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 232).

question: What is a common method for drawing an ellipse in isometric view when using instruments?

options.b: The four-center method
options.c: Using a standard circle template

explanation: The four-center method is usually used when drawing an isometric ellipse with drawing instruments (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 202).

question: Why are hidden lines generally omitted from sectional views?

options.b: Because the purpose of the section is to make interior features visible, thus eliminating the need for hidden lines
options.c: Because hidden lines are too thick for sections

explanation: Hidden lines are normally omitted from section views because the section itself exposes the interior features, making them visible (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 251, 263, 279).

question: Which type of drawing projection gives the most realistic representation of an object as the human eye sees it?

options.b: Isometric projection
options.c: Perspective projection

explanation: Perspective drawings are more realistic than any other type of drawing projection because they show how objects appear to the human eye, with parallel lines converging as they recede into the distance (ET-GC03 Manual, p. 228).
